```{r}
library(tidyverse)

```

## Data

Vizualizatsiya uchun avtomobil narxlari va unga tegishli boshqa ma'lumotlardan iborat quyidagi dataset'dan foydalanamiz. Dastlab datani import qilamiz:

```{r}
chevrole_cars <- read_excel("chevrole_cars.xlsx") %>% 
  sample_n(1000)
```

Endi ushbu dataset ma'lumotlarini inspeksiya qilamiz:

```{r}
# datatable(
#   chevrole_cars,
#   filter = 'top')
```

## **R base orqali vizualizatsiya**

Hech qanday packagelarsiz R'ning ichki funksiyalari yordamida ham grafiklar yaratish mumkin. Masalan, scatter plot yarataylik:

```{r}
plot(price~mileage, data=chevrole_cars)
```

Yoki histogram:

```{r}
hist(x=chevrole_cars$price)
```

Muammo ushbu grafiklarga "ishlov" berishda boshlanadi.

::: panel-tabset
## Base scatter plot

```{r}
plot(price~mileage, data=chevrole_cars,
     main = "Narx va Masofa o'rtasidagi bog'liqlik",
     xlab = "masofa (km)", ylab = "Narx (dollarda)",
     pch = 19, frame = FALSE)
abline(lm(price~mileage, data = chevrole_cars), col = "blue")
```

## Base histogram

```{r}
hist(x=chevrole_cars$price,
     breaks = 12,
     col = "darkred",
     main = "Avtomobil narxlari taqsimoti",
     xlab = "Narxlar",
     ylab = "soni")
```
:::

Bunday tartibda kod yozish chalkashtiradi va noqulay.

## **ggplot2 bilan murakkabroq grafiklar yaratish**

Ushbu muammoning yechimi - [{ggplot2}](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) ðŸ“¦ package. Ushbu packageni yaratuvchisi [Hadley Wickham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadley_Wickham) hisoblanadi (Chief Scientist at RStudio/Posit) va [{tidyverse}](https://tidyverse.tidyverse.org/) ðŸ“¦ tarkibi sifatida uning prinsiplariga amal qiladi. Bundan tashqari mazkur package chuqur vizualizatisya nazariyasiga asoslangan (Leland Uilkinsonning [*Grafika grammatikasi*](https://www.amazon.com/Grammar-Graphics-Statistics-Computing/dp/0387245448) ).

### ggplot2 elementlari

Ushbu packageni eng yaxshi tomoni u grafiklar grammatikasi *(grammar of graphics)* prinsiplaridan foydalangan holda grafiklar yaratadi.

ggplot2 "grafiklar grammatikasi"ning eng muhim prinsiplardan biri **grafiklar pirog singari qatlam-qatlam qilib yaratiladi**.

Bu mavhum tuyulishi tabiiy. Shuning uchun ggplot'ning har bir elementini ko'rib chiqamiz.

If we just runÂ [`ggplot()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggplot.html), weâ€™ll get a blank canvas.

```{r}
ggplot()
```

Now we have to add our dataset and what our axes will be.

Whenever we are talking about a **variable** from our dataset, we have to put it inside the [`aes()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/aes.html) argument, which stands for **aesthetics**.

```{r}
ggplot(data = chevrole_cars,
       mapping=aes(x = mileage,
           y = price))
```

In fact, as ggplot2 works in layers, we can use it as follows:

```{r}
ggplot(data = chevrole_cars)+
  aes(x = mileage,
      y = price)
```

::: callout-note
## Esda tuting

### **`+` location**

One common problem when creating ggplot2 graphics is to put the `+` in the wrong place: it has to come at the end of a line, not the start. In other words, make sure you havenâ€™t accidentally written code like this:

```{r}
# ggplot(data = chevrole_cars)
# +aes(x = mileage,
#       y = price)
```
:::

AsÂ **ggplot2**Â is part of theÂ [{tidyverse}](https://tidyverse.tidyverse.org/)Â ðŸ“¦, we can tell R in the imperative:Â *â€œGet the datasetÂ `chevrole_cars`Â and then create the ggplotâ€¦â€*. The good thing about this approach is that, as ggplot already knows the dataset beforehand, it helps us select the variables (pressÂ `tab`Â before writing the variables).

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))
```

Now we have our chart with the axes delimited, and we can add as many layers as we like. The principle of ggplot is similar to pipe, where the information is passed directly to the layer below, so we donâ€™t need to add the data again.

::: callout-important
## Esda tuting

No need to write explicitly write out `data =`, `mapping =`, `x =`, and `y =` each time in `ggplot`. `ggplot` code in the wild often omit these argument names. Yuqoridagi kodni qisqaroq formasi:

```{r}
# chevrole_cars %>% 
#   ggplot(aes(mileage,
#              price))
```
:::

### **Geometries**

Geometries are functions that start withÂ `geom_*`. There are lots of them and we can get a little help withÂ [ggplot2 cheatsheet](https://posit.co/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/data-visualization-1.pdf). The geom determines how the data is shown

First, letâ€™s create a scatterplot

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))+
  geom_point()
```

To add another layer of geometry, just add another layer to this canvas. Letâ€™s add a trend line with theÂ [`geom_smooth()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_smooth.html)Â function.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_smooth()
```

We can add a linear trend line with the argumentÂ `method = "lm"`!

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```

Here we can see how ggplot2 works like a painting. As [`geom_smooth()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_smooth.html) was called **after** [`geom_point()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_point.html), it is plotted on top.

Letâ€™s look at the same example but inverting these geometries.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))+
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")+
  geom_point()
```

Letâ€™s make a boxplot/violinplot/dotplot (using theÂ `geom_boxplot`Â geometry) of the type of cars by model

::: panel-tabset
## boxplot

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = model, y = price))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

## violinplot

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = model, y = price))+
  geom_violin()
```

## dotplot

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = model, y = price))+
  geom_point()
```
:::

Now letâ€™s make a bar chart (using theÂ `geom_bar()`Â geometry) of the car's models.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = model))+
  geom_bar()
```

We can invert the axes, just switch. Especially with large texts, itâ€™s best to keep them on the y-axis.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model))+
  geom_bar()
```

The models are not in the order we would like (as in the dataset), they are in alphabetical order. So we have to sort them byÂ `id`, but to be sorted we need to consider them as factors.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  count(model) %>% 
  arrange(n) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = reorder(model, n), x = n))+
  geom_col()
```

What if we want to display percentages? Here we should compute percentages first, then plot the data:

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  count(model, name = 'count') %>% 
  mutate(percentage = 100 * count / sum(count)) %>%  # calculate percentage
  ggplot() +
  geom_col(aes(x = model, y = percentage))

```

These charts are missing **colors**! Buning uchun biz geom() bilan birga foydalaniluvchi aes() ning boshqa elementlarini ko'rib chiqamiz.

O'zgartirish mumkin bo'lgan argumentlar:

-   `colour`: change the colour (if point or line) or outline (if bar or histogram) of the markings

-   `fill`: Change the colour of bars in bar charts or histograms.

-   `size`: change the size of the markings (if point used)

::: column-margin
Type colours() into the console to see a list of all the named colours in R. Alternatively, you can use hexadecimal colours like "#FF8000" or the rgb() function to set red, green, and blue values on a scale from 0 to 1.
:::

-   `shape`: change the shape of markings (for points)

    ![](shape-demo-1.png)

-   `linewidth`: Change the line width

-   `linetype`: Choose the type of line (e.g.Â `dotted`)

    ![](linetype-demo-1.png)

-   `alpha`: Change the transparency of a visualisation (0 = Totally transparent, 1 = totally opaque).

Now letâ€™s use the `color` and `fill` arguments. `color` applies color to points, lines, text, borders. `fill` applies color to any filled areas.

We can color according to any variable, in this case weâ€™ll color by **type**.

```{r}
chevrole_cars <- chevrole_cars %>% 
  mutate(segment = case_when(model == "Malibu" ~ "Qimmat", 
                             model == "Captiva" ~ "Qimmat",
                             model == "Tracker" ~ "Qimmat",
                             .default = "Byudjet")
         )
  
```

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar()
```

Now we can add the outline. As itâ€™s not a variable (itâ€™s a fixed color), it doesnâ€™t have to go insideÂ [`aes()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/aes.html)

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black",  alpha = 0.5)
```

Scatter plot orqali qolgan argumentlarni o'zgartirib ko'ramiz.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  filter(mileage > 10000) %>% 
  ggplot()+
  geom_point(aes(mileage, price, color=model, shape = is_petrol), alpha = 0.8)
```

::: callout-note
## Esda tuting

### **Aesthetic mappings**

To map an aesthetic to a variable, set the name of the aesthetic equal to the name of the variable, and do this inside `mapping = aes()`. ggplot2 will automatically assign a unique level of the aesthetic (here a unique color) to each unique value of the variable. ggplot2 will also add a legend that explains which levels correspond to which values.

This insight gives us a new way to think about the mapping argument. Mappings tell ggplot2 more than which variables to put on which axes, they tell ggplot2 which variables to map to which visual properties. The x and y locations of each point are just two of the many visual properties displayed by a point.
:::

Misol uchun, nuqtalarni barchasini ko'k rang qilmoqchi bo'lsak, color argumentini aes() dan tashqarida ishlatishimiz va xoxlayotgan rangni belgilashimiz kerak:

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  filter(mileage > 1000) %>% 
  ggplot()+
  geom_point(aes(mileage, price, shape = is_petrol), color = "blue", alpha = 0.5)
```

### **Labels**

Every chart can have a title, subtitle, caption, axis title, etc.

All this can be determined using the [`labs()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/labs.html) function within ggplot. Note that the legend is created according to the `fill` variable, so the title of the legend will follow this variable.

```{r}

chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  labs(
    title = "Modellar soni",
    subtitle = "Sampledagi avto modellar soni",
    caption = "Nozimjon Ortikov",
    x = "Soni",
    y = "Model",
    fill = "Model turi"
  )
```

::: column-margin
Yana bir variant

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  xlab("soni")+
  ylab ("Model")+
  ggtitle("Modellar soni")+
  labs(
    subtitle = "Sampledagi avto modellar soni",
    caption = "Nozimjon Ortikov",
    fill = "Model turi"
  )
```
:::

### **Scales**

Scales functions customize the x and y axes. Scales control the details of how data values are translated to visual properties. Shu sababdan barcha turdagi `aes()`lar uchun `scale_*()` funksiyalari mavjud.

-   positions via `scale_x_*()` va `scale_y_*()` orqali.

    -   extenstions (\*) o'rnida `continuous()`, `discrete()`, `reverse()`, `log10()`, `sqrt()`, `date()` lar kelishi mumkin

-   colors `scale_color_*()` va `scale_fill_*()` orqali o'zgartiriladi.

    -   extenstions (\*) o'rnida `continuous()`, `discrete()`, `manual()`, `gradient()`, `gradient2()`, `brewer()` kabi extenstionslar kelishi mumkin

Common arguments forÂ **continuous**Â variables are:

```{r}
#| echo: false 
#| warning: false
#| error: false

# scale_y_continuous( 
#   # Set the lower & upper boundaries
#   limits = c(lower, upper),
#   # Explicitly set the break points
#   breaks = c(break1, break2, etc.),
#   # Adjust the axis so bars start at 0
#   expand = expand_scale(mult = c(0, 0.05))
# )
```

Letâ€™s edit the x axis. The breaks are every 20 attack points, letâ€™s put them every 10 points. As the x-axis is continuous, weâ€™ll use the `scale_x_continuous()` function. The `breaks` argument helps us with this task!

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_x_continuous(
    name = "Soni", 
    #breaks = seq(0, 250, 20), 
    #breaks = c(0, 50, 100, 150, 200), 
    breaks = 0:5*50, 
    limits = c(0, 250), 
    #labels = c("0", "50 ta", "100 ta", "150 ta", "200 ta"),
    labels = paste(0:5*50, "ta"),
    #expand = expansion(mult = c(0.01, 0.05)),
    expand = expand_scale(mult = c(0, 0.05)),
    # expand = c(0,0),
    #expand = c(0.2, 1)
    #expand = c(0, NA)
    )
```

Scatter plotni scale elementlari orqali o'zgartiramiz:

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  # filter(mileage > 1000) %>% 
  ggplot()+
  # geom_point(aes(mileage, price, shape = is_petrol),
  #            color = "blue", alpha = 0.5)+
  geom_point(aes(mileage/10^3, price/10^3, shape = is_petrol),
             color = "blue", alpha = 0.5)+
  # scale_x_continuous(labels = label_number_auto(),
  #                    expand = c(0.01,0.05))+
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_number_auto(),
                     expand = c(0.01,0.05)) +
  # scale_y_continuous(labels = label_dollar(scale = 1/1000))+
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 0:5*100,
    labels = paste(0:5*100, "ming km"),
    expand = c(0.02,0.05)
    )

```

Scale funksiyasi orqali x va y o'qlardagi ma'lumotlarni transformatsiya ham qilish mumkin. Narx va Masofa o'rtasidagi bog'liqlikni logarifmik scaleda ko'rish uchun `scale_x_log10` yoki `scale_y_log10` funksiyalaridan foydalanish mumin:

```{r}
#| layout-ncol: 2
#| column: page

#scales orqali transformatsiya

chevrole_cars %>% 
  # filter(mileage > 1000) %>% 
  ggplot()+
  geom_point(aes(mileage, price, shape = is_petrol),
             color = "blue", alpha = 0.5)+
  scale_x_log10()+
  scale_y_log10()

#qo'lda transformatsiya qilish

chevrole_cars %>% 
  # filter(mileage > 1000) %>% 
  ggplot()+
  geom_point(aes(log10(mileage), log10(price), shape = is_petrol),
             color = "blue", alpha = 0.5)
```

Colors can also be defined using the `scale_*` function. These colors are not exactly what we want, we can define them manually using the [`scale_fill_manual()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/scale_manual.html) function.

As the colors are defined according to type, weâ€™ll use them as a basis. For the **byudjet** type weâ€™ll use the color `#6890F0`â—‰, for the **qimmat** type weâ€™ll use the color `#F08030`â—‰

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )
```

### **Annotations**

```{r}
#| layout-ncol: 2
#| column: page

chevrole_cars %>% 
  count(model) %>% 
  arrange(n) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = reorder(model, n), x = n))+
  geom_col()+
  geom_text(aes(label = n, x= n - 5), 
            size = 5,
            color = "white", 
            hjust = 1)


chevrole_cars %>% 
  filter(mileage > 1000) %>% 
  sample_n(50) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))+
   geom_point()+
   geom_text(aes(label= model), check_overlap = TRUE, hjust = -0.2) 
```

If you want to label many points, it is difficult to avoid overlaps.Â `check_overlap = TRUE`Â is useful, but offers little control over which labels are removed. A popular technique for addressing this is to use the ggrepel packageÂ <https://github.com/slowkow/ggrepel>Â by Kamil Slowikowski. The package suppliesÂ `geom_text_repel()`, which optimizes the label positioning to avoid overlap. It works quite well so long as the number of labels is not excessive:

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  filter(mileage > 1000) %>%
  sample_n(50) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price))+
   geom_point()+
   geom_text_repel(aes(label= model), 
                   max.overlaps = Inf,
                   box.padding = 0.3 #controls how far labels are placed from data points
                   ) 
```

## **Direct labelling**

```{r}

#| layout-ncol: 2
#| column: page

chevrole_cars %>% 
  filter(mileage > 1000) %>%
  sample_n(50) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price,
             colour = is_petrol)
         )+
   geom_point()


chevrole_cars %>% 
  filter(mileage > 1000) %>%
  sample_n(50) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price,
             colour = is_petrol)
         )+
  geom_point(show.legend = FALSE)+
  geom_smooth(method= 'lm', se = FALSE)+
  directlabels::geom_dl(aes(label = is_petrol), method = "smart.grid")
```

### **Themes**

But these charts arenâ€™t so pretty yet, we can edit **anything** in the charts, from the background color to the font!

ggplot2 already has some pre-defined themes. Letâ€™s try them out

This is [`theme_bw()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html)

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  theme_bw()
```

I really likeÂ [`theme_classic()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html)

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  theme_classic()
```

[`theme_minimal()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html)Â is also widely used.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  theme_minimal()
```

TheÂ [`theme_void()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html)Â maintainsÂ **only**Â the geometries of the generated chart.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  theme_void()
```

But we can edit anything within the chosen theme too. These functions are just predetermined configurations.

![Theme'ning elementlari](Ð¡Ð½Ð¸Ð¼Ð¾Ðº%20ÑÐºÑ€Ð°Ð½Ð°%202024-09-21%20192604.png)

Most of the parameters can be seen [on this website](https://ggplot2tor.com/theme). To change the theme parameters, we add the arguments to the `theme()` function.

#### **`theme`: modify the *look* of texts** (`element text()`)

Many different ways to style text:

-   font size

-   Font face (**bold**, *italic*, [small caps]{.smallcaps})

-   Font family ( Times New Roman, Calibri, Arial, Hi friends )

-   Font color, letter spacing, angle, weight, etc.

Often times you'll likely only have access to a limited set:

-   Font size, font family, and limited set of font styles

-   But you can get pretty far with these!

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  labs(
    title = "Modellar soni",
    subtitle = "Sampledagi avto modellar soni",
    caption = "Nozimjon Ortikov",
    x = "Soni",
    y = "Model",
    fill = "Model turi"
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size = 30,
                                 color = "red",
                                 face = "bold",
                                 angle = 10,
                                 family = "Fira Code"),
       legend.title = element_text(size = 25,
                                   color = "#ef42eb", 
                                   margin = margin(b = 5)),
       plot.title = element_text(size = 35,
                                 face = "bold",
                                 family = "Nunito",
                                 color = "blue"
                                ),
       axis.text.y.left = element_text(size = 14, 
                                       face = "bold"
                                       )
       )
```

#### `theme`: modifying the look of the rectangular regions (`element_rect()`)

`element_rect()` yordamida grafikning backgroundini o'zgartirish mumkin. E'tibor berin `plot`Â - butun grafik vaÂ `panel` ikkita o'qning orasidagi grafik qismi.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  theme(legend.background = element_rect(fill = "#fff6c2", 
                                  color = "black",
                               linetype = "dashed"),
        legend.key = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "brown"),
        panel.background = element_rect(fill = "yellow"),
        panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", 
                              fill = "transparent",
                    linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 1),
        plot.background = element_rect(fill = "pink"),
        legend.position = "bottom"
        )
```

#### **`theme`: modify the *look* of the lines (`element_line()`)**

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
 theme(axis.line.y = element_line(color = "black",
                                  size = 1.2,
                                  arrow = grid::arrow()),
       axis.line.x = element_line(linetype = "dashed", 
                                  color = "brown",
                                  size = 1.2),
       axis.ticks = element_line(color = "red", linewidth = 1.1),
       axis.ticks.length = unit(5, "mm"),
       panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "blue", 
                                       size = 1.2),
       panel.grid.minor = element_line(color = "#0080ff",
                                       size = 1.2,
                                       linetype = "dotted"))
```

Ushbu grafiklar shunchaki ko'rsatish maqsadida yasaldi.

#### Margins & Spacing

```{r}
#| layout-ncol: 2
#| column: page

chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  labs(
    title = "Modellar soni",
    subtitle = "Sampledagi avto modellar soni",
    caption = "Nozimjon Ortikov",
    x = "Soni",
    y = "Model",
    fill = "Model turi"
  )+
  theme_minimal()

chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment))+
  geom_bar(color = "black")+
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  )+
  labs(
    title = "Modellar soni",
    subtitle = "Sampledagi avto modellar soni",
    caption = "Nozimjon Ortikov",
    x = "Soni",
    y = "Model",
    fill = "Model turi"
  )+
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.margin = margin(1, .8, .8, .8, "cm"),
    plot.title = element_text(margin = margin(b = .3, unit = "cm")),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(margin = margin(b = .3, unit = "cm")),
    axis.text.x = element_text(margin = margin(t = .2, unit = "cm")),
```

### **Facets**

We often have a lot of information to show in just one chart. For this we can use the idea ofÂ **small multiples**Â with theÂ [`facet_wrap()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/facet_wrap.html)Â function!

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price,
             color = model))+
  geom_point()+
  facet_wrap(.~model)
```

We can use the facets with other data too.

```{r}
chevrole_cars %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mileage,
             y = price,
             ))+
  geom_point()+
  facet_wrap(.~segment)
```

## **Combining plots with `patchwork`**

```{r}
# Your individual plots
g1 <- chevrole_cars %>%
  ggplot(aes(y = model, fill = segment)) +
  geom_bar(color = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Byudjet" = "#6890F0",
      "Qimmat" = "#F08030"
    )
  ) +
  labs(tag = "A)") +
  theme_minimal()

g2 <- chevrole_cars %>%
  filter(mileage > 1000) %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(mileage, price, shape = is_petrol), color = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(tag = "B)") +
  theme_minimal()

combined_plot <- g1 + g2 
print(combined_plot)
```

## Setting your theme

Birinchi navbatda o'zimizning theme'ni set qivolishimiz kerak.

Always start with a base theme, likeÂ [`theme_minimal()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html)Â and set the size and font. Keyinchalik ustiga qolgan elementlarini qo'shib ketish mumkin.

```{r}
# set up custom theme to add to all plots
mytheme <- theme_minimal(     # always start with a base theme_****
  base_size = 16,             # 16-point font (adjusted for axes)
  base_family = "Roboto Slab"      # custom font family
)+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20),
        plot.title.position = "plot",
        plot.subtitle = element_text(face = "italic"))
```
